Dear Ms. Lawson:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
2/23/2024. An Exit conference was held with the agency onsite on 2/29/2024. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within
45 calendar days after receipt of the information. If
additional time is required, then the agency shall inform
the foster parent, in writing, of the basis for the extension
and the expected length of the extension. The total time
for the completion of the investigation may not exceed 90
calendar days without written approval from the chief
administrator or his or her designee.
1 of 4 special evaluations reviewed showed that the evaluation surpassed 90 days
and the written approval by the chief administrator or designee was completed after
the 90-day timeframe.
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of
conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
department, bureau of fire services, or local
authorities; records; report; forms; confidentiality;
disclosure of information; availability of confidential
records; child information cards to be provided to
department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
i nvestigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care
and shall report to the department, when requested, the
2

facts the department requires with reference to the
children upon forms furnished by the department. Except
as otherwise provided in this subsection and subsection
(4), records regarding children and facts compiled about
children and their parents and relatives are confidential
and disclosure of this information shall be properly
safeguarded by the child care organization, the
department, and any other entity in possession of the
information. Records that are confidential under this
section are available to both of the following:
In 2 of 4 special evaluations records reviewed the evaluation showed CPS (child
protective services) and or MIC (maltreatment in care) language and showed CPS’s
involvement in the investigation. The evaluations listed the MIC/CPS worker.
ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment.
Child Adoption Assessment Timeframes:
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be
completed by the adoption worker and approved by the
adoption supervisor within 45 calendar days of case
acceptance.
Prior to completing the child adoption assessment, the
adoption worker must make a minimum of two face-to-
face contacts with the child, with at least one in the
home, and one face-to-face with the child's current
caregiver, even if the caregiver(s) are not interested in
adopting the child. The contacts must be documented in
the child assessment.
2 of 8 open adoption child records reviewed did not show compliance. In one record
the child’s child adoption assessment did not show two face to face contacts as
required by the policy and the second record showed the child’s adoption
assessment due by 1/7/2023 was completed 5 days late.
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
3

Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward Service
Plan (PWSP) – within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
1 of 8 open foster child records reviewed; and 1 of 3 open independent living youth
records reviewed did not show compliance as the USP FTM was completed as
required.

January 2023 Renewal inspection, CAP approved on 2/24/2023.

Agreement and signature:

obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:

household.
Youth ages 14 and older.
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12209(1) Orientation and training.
• The agency was apprised that the required training documentation for
persons promoted from worker to supervisor, and any worker who
transfers from one child welfare position to another, shall consistently be
on file at the time of the department’s file review.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12312(4) Foster Parent Training.
• The agency was advised that consistently uploading the foster parent’s CPR
and first aid training certificates can aid it in showing compliance to the rule.
R 400.12511(2)(d) Termination
• The agency was advised placing a statement within the body of the youth’s
closing action summary that the youth received all their funds and personal
belongings may aid it in showing compliance to this rule.
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Report.
• The agency was advised placing the quarterly reporting period time frame
on the top of the document, and indicating the date of the home visit with
the child and family within the child’s current placement and functioning
section of that quarterly progress report may aid it in showing clearer
5

documentation of the accurate quarterly reporting period, and the date of the
quarterly face to face home visit with the child and family.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There wasone incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The incident related to an allegation that the foster father hit his foster son’s
hand because the child took the child’s brother’s Uno cards. Also, that the foster
mother pushed the child at the park. During the investigation the foster parent
admitted to tapping the child’s hand during the Uno incident. The foster mother
denied the allegation about the push, and there was insufficient evidence to show
that occurred. The foster home was found in violation of the behavior management
rule, and a corrective action plan was developed with the family, which entailed the
foster parents re-reviewing policy and resigning the agency’s discipline policy. The
agency adhered to departmental timeframes and requirements related to this
special evaluations.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted two corrective action plans not related to maltreatment
during the inspection period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2023 Renewal inspection
where they received the following rule violations:
• R400.12327(5)(d) Special evaluation.
• R400.12405 (5) (a) &(b)Change of placement.
• R400.12413 (1) (c)(ii) Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12418(2)(a) & (b) Development of Service Plans.
• R400.12419(1)(c) Initial Service Plans.
• R400.12421(a) Visitation and parenting time.
• R400.12607(4) Agency recommendation.
• MISEP 4.22 Child Welfare Information System (Commitment 22)
• MISEP 6.19(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (commitment 69)
• FOM 722-6b Family Team Meeting.
• FOM 722-8- Case Service Plans-Overview, Types & Timeframes-Supervisory
Approval.
• FOM 722-8 D Treatment Plans-Agreements & Signatures
• FOM 722-8-E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
• FOM 801- C Medial Passport.
• FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental Need of Children
under Supervision o MDHHS,
The agency received three repeat violations this inspection. Notwithstanding that,
or its continued staff turnover, which also included administrative changes for chief
operating officer and chief executive officer, the agency made significant progress
6

on this corrective action plan. It provided information showing efforts to remind
foster care, adoption, and licensing workers of timeframes and due dates,
utilization of outlook calendars for such purposes; tools to review case records for
compliance, and completion of various training (i.e. family team meetings, closing
action summaries). The agency also held meetings, discussions, on the corrective
action plan, as verified, and also affirmed by the staff interviewed. The file reviews
also showed observation of various tools, checklists and efforts being utilized to
aid staff in program rule compliance.
The agency’s second corrective action plan related to special investigation
2024C0000896SI, for a complaint received on11/3/2023. The allegation was that
a foster parent abruptly dropped a foster child’s belonging off without providing a
14-day notice; and the agency did not initiate a special evaluation against the
foster parent. Additionally, that the agency placed an intensive needs child into a
new inexperienced foster family home who had no adequate training and was
licensed less than six months. The agency was not found in violation of the first
allegation; but was with respect to the second. The agency was cited for
R400.12325 related to Agency recommendation for not adequately documenting
its rationale for recommending several high need services type children for this
foster home, given the homes lack of completed training and personal experience.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan, which was approved
12/15/2023. The agency reported it would conduct a Team’s training for staff on
the license service type utilizing the technical assistance manual by 1/4/2024.
Additionally, supervisors will review foster home licensing assessment’s, service
type and recommendation for placement and compare that with what’s is
documented in the CWLM (Child Welfare Licensing Module) system. This review
is to ensure for the appropriate service types, and the child’s need so as to
determine the suitability of a potential placement. New home study checklists and
Annual study checklists will also be used to help gauge intake and licensing
workers in making these determination and the review of such. Proof of these
checklists was provided during the onsite visit for this Interim inspection on
2/13/2024; along with proof of License Service Type training completed for staff
via PowerPoint. The agency also provided sample emails showing how it is
exploring placement suitability of a foster home for children prior to giving approval
for the placement. The agency appears to be complying with this corrective action
plan.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator (CA)provided an annual chief administrator's report dated
10/3/2023 for 10/1/2022-9/30/2023 which was completed per the requirement rule
and did not show any notable areas of concern.
The CA reported barriers or systemic factors that impacted the agency’s
compliance to rule/policy included, delays in data entry from child welfare foster
care/the department of health and human services (DHHS) staff, delays with title-
IVE case reads, delays in assignment of cases in MISACWIS, all necessary
information not moving onto permanent wards cases from temporary ones, and
7

YAVFC eligibility discrepancies between the local DHHS office and policy office;
as well as spreadsheet sent by multiple DHHS entities at various times each
month the need responses. The CA believes the agency’s 2023 CAP had some
impact on the agency’s overall non-compliance; and that the agency saw
improvements in a number of key performance indicator areas, inclusive of fac-to-
face contacts, initial and updated service plan timeliness from workers and
supervisors.
The CA reported the agency had both administrative and line staff turnover; and
has worked to fill all positions. The CA reported the agency will continue to use the
MMR (Monthly Management Record) and BOB (Book of Business) on an
individual staff basis, as well as, on a larger compliance basis to ensure the
agency is meeting the KPI standards. Additionally, that these standards and CAP
compliance will be shared with staff at twice monthly staff meetings; and checklists
and case file reviews are being utilized to ensure compliance.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a 10/1/2023- 9/30/2024 consolidated budget, 2024
preliminary budget, and an independent financial audit for 2023. A review of the
documents did not show any specific areas of concern.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, the licensing
designee/program officer; and three other administrative/managerial staff, one
supervisor, one foster care/adoption worker, one licensing worker, and one foster
care worker was interviewed. The staff reported positives about the agency’s
ability to cater to its employees’ strengths, teamwork, putting children first, and the
agency’s willingness to fill in financial gaps to meet children and family needs
when program services are unable to fulfill that need. Additionally, the agency’s
awareness of salary lapses and its recent willingness to explore salary upgrades
was also noted. Areas of concern or needs for growth reported by staff related to a
need to continue working on staff retention and salary increases.
One independent living youth was interviewed, and the youth reported being
helped by the agency. Aside from wishing the worker would always have an
answer to questions upfront, no concerns were reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility did not reveal any safety issues or concerns.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert, which was received on 1/11/2024:
Concern:
The foster parents did not respond to several attempts by the DCWL (Division of
Child Welfare Licensing) Analyst to schedule a visit in the home for the annual audit.
8

The safety of the home was not able to be assessed due to the foster parents not
responding.
Resolution:
The agency contacted the foster father on 1/11/2024 and he reported frustration with
having been selected for a home visit because he had been selected in a prior year.
The agency advised the foster parent of his and his wife’s responsibility to
participate in this progress and to contact the DCWL Analyst. A foster home
assessment visit occurred at the foster home by the agency’s licensing worker on
1/11/2024 around 5:30pm. The home was observed to be tidy, and there were no
safety concerns noted. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were operable,
there were adequate sleeping arrangements, and there were no observable hazards
in the home or yard.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
